title: 107_s3096
content: The "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" or the "BLAST Act" aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of all new firearms for sale and those in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITION OF BALLISTICS. The term 'ballistics' means a comparative analysis of fired bullets and cartridge casings to identify the firearm from which they were discharged. SEC. 4. TEST FIRING AND AUTOMATED STORAGE OF BALLISTICS RECORDS. Amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, store records in a database, and store fired bullet and cartridge casings as specified by the Secretary. No civil liability except for civil penalties imposed under this section. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist firearm manufacturers and importers in complying with regulations related to ballistics equipment, database maintenance, and education on firearm crime reduction strategies. No civil liability except for civil penalties imposed under this section. The Attorney General and the Secretary will develop and maintain a database of ballistics images, provide education on ballistics role in firearm crime reduction, coordinate with law enforcement agencies and the firearm industry, establish a computer system for accessing ballistics records, and encourage training for ballistics examiners. The Attorney General and the Secretary will submit an annual report to Congress on the impact of the section, including the use of ballistics records in criminal investigations and prosecutions, accessibility of records across jurisdictions, and training for ballistics examiners. The annual report to Congress will include information on the value of ballistics records in criminal cases, accessibility of records across jurisdictions, and evaluation of test programs. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2001-2004 for equipment installation, testing sites, personnel salaries, and research. The Secretary and the Attorney General shall conduct mandatory ballistics testing of all firearms obtained or in their possession. Effective Date: The amendment shall take effect upon certification of interoperable ballistics systems by the Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury. The Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury must certify interoperable ballistics systems for mandatory testing of new firearms. Section 923(m)(1) of title 18, United States Code, will take effect 5 years after enactment, while section 923(m)(6) will be effective immediately. SEC. 5. PRIVACY RIGHTS OF LAW ABIDING CITIZENS. Ballistics information of individual guns cannot be used for prosecution unless there is a reasonable belief that a crime has been committed and the information would help in the investigation.
